Hi Ken,

From what I see, this app should be a really good tool to help me =

understand the internal workings of the CPPNs. Would you provide me a 
bri=
ef guideness on how to implement that myself and use it? 

So what matters =
the most is the additions and subtractions of the 
values that get into the=
 hidden nodes? I assume you mean the "output 
=3D function( sum(i1 * w1 + i=
2 * w2 + ... + in * wn + bias) )". Then 
actually the weights of the connec=
tions inputting into the node are 
really more important than the preceeedi=
ng functions above it. Of 
course, if a weight is close to zero then it has=
 almost no influence 
to the node. In a stream of conciosness I am continui=
ng with some 
questions. OK then when 2 or more links output to the same no=
de, it 
is combining them or in other words, adding/subtracting them, right=
. 
Did you see any difference with lower "add-link" mutation rates? 
Where =
more nodes are being added with only one input and one output 
link? 
I kno=
w what the weights themselves mean, they are scalars of the 
coordinate fra=
mes. I am also aware of what happens when a function (a 
coordinate frame) =
is laid on top of another. But how do you explain 
the situation where 2 or=
 more coordinate frames are being added 
together? Are we able to actually =
analyze that in a deterministic way 
without using evolution to see stuff? =
See, I know this is possible, 
but I am looking for the easy and clean way,=
 you know.. 

Peter

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanl=
ey@...> wrote:
>
> We actually did at one time create an internal app that =
lets you do
> this with Picbreeder images.  We could click on a node in a C=
PPN and
> see the pattern generated at that internal node (which is like an=

> intermediate stage of development).  It's very enlightening.  One
> thin=
g it taught me is that a lot of the shapes are created through
> additions =
and subtractions, in addition to compositions.  But those
> additions and s=
ubtractions are very important.  
> 
> Unfortunately that app has not been =
further developed at this time 
and
> is no longer compatible with Picbreed=
er.  Perhaps we will get back 
to
> it so that it can be made available at =
some point.
> 
> ken
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune <jclune@>=
 wrote:
> >
> > > So I'm thinking that the benchmark result is less importa=
nt 
than the
> > > comprehension of how the encoding built its results.  CP=
PNs 
have the
> > > nice property that they are fairly straightforward.  Yo=
u can 
look at
> > > each hidden node and look at the intermediate structur=
e that it
> > > produces.  In e.g. a GRN-based system, on the other hand, i=
t's
> > > significantly more opaque and difficult to explain, and 
therefor=
e more
> > > difficult to bias.
> > 
> > Have you done this Ken? Was it hel=
pful to understand what was 
going on?
> > 
> > Do you guys have a tool tha=
t makes this easy to do? I think it 
would
> be very
> > instructive to be =
able to look at the contribution of hidden 
nodes and
> > subgraphs of the =
CPPN network.
> > 
> > jeff
> >
